awd_titl_txt: EAGER: GreenDataFlow: Minimizing the Energy Footprint of Global Data Movement
awd_abstract_narration:
This project fills an important gap in the understanding of data transfer energy efficiency.  The models, algorithms and tools developed as part of this project will help increase performance and decrease power consumption during end-to-end data transfers, which should save significant quantities of resources (estimated to be gigawatt-hours of energy and millions of dollars in the US economy alone).  The applicability and efficiency of these novel techniques will be evaluated in actual applications, in a collaborative partnership with IBM.

The project explores options for minimizing the energy-use footprint of global data movement. The effort is focused on saving energy at the end systems (sender and receiver nodes) during data transfer.  It explores a novel approach to achieving low-energy end-to-end data transfers, through application-layer energy-aware throughput optimization. The research team investigates and analyzes the factors that affect performance and energy consumption in end-to-end data transfers, such as CPU frequency scaling, multi-core scheduling, I/O block size, TCP buffer size, and the level of parallelism, concurrency, and pipelining, along with the data transfer rates at the network routers, switches, and hubs.   How these parameters decrease energy consumption in the end systems and networking infrastructure, without sacrificing transfer performance, are assessed.  The project will create novel application-layer models, algorithms, and tools for:
 - predicting the best combination of end-system and protocol parameters for optimal data transfer throughput with energy-efficiency constraints; 
 - accurately predicting the network device power consumption due to increased data transfer rate on the active links, and dynamic readjustment of the transfer rate to balance the energy performance ratio; and 
 - providing service level agreement (SLA) based energy-efficient transfer algorithms to service providers. 
The models, algorithms and tools developed as part of this project will help increase performance and decrease power consumption during end-to-end data transfers, saving significant quantities of resources.  Since the tools focus on the application layer, they will not require changes to the existing infrastructure, nor to the low-level networking stack, and wide deployment of the developed system should be readily attainable.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

This project resulted in several novel models and algorithms for energy-efficient data transfer optimization. These include:

(1) A novel application-layer solution, called GreenDataFlow, based on historical analysis and real-time tuning, that aims to achieve high data transfer throughput while keeping energy consumption minimal. GreenDataFlow supports service level agreements (SLAs) which give the service providers and the consumers the ability to fine-tune their goals and priorities in this optimization process. The experimental results show that GreenDataFlow outperforms the closest competing state-of-the-art solution in this area 50% for energy-saving and 2.5X for the achieved end-to-end performance. This work was presented at the IEEE BIGDATA 2018 Conference.

(2) An in-depth analysis of the effects of application-layer data transfer protocol parameters on the energy consumption of mobile phones and the development of a novel model, called FastHLA, that can achieve significant energy savings at the application layer during mobile network I/O without sacrificing performance. The experimental evaluation results show that FastHLA achieves performance increase and energy-saving simultaneously in most cases. This work was presented at the ACM MOBIWAC 2018 Conference.

(3) An in-depth analysis of several application-level parameters that affect the end-to-end data transfer throughput and the total energy consumption during HTTP data transfers and the development of several novel service-level-agreement (SLA) based joint optimization algorithms which can decide the best combination of these parameters considering user-defined energy efficiency and performance criteria. The experimental results show that up to 80% of energy savings can be achieved at the client and server hosts during HTTP data transfers while simultaneously increasing the end-to-end transfer throughput. This work was published in the Information Sciences Journal, 2019.

(4) A novel cross-layer optimization framework that jointly considers application-level and kernel-level parameters to minimize energy consumption without sacrificing the transfer throughput. The experimental results show that these algorithms outperform the state-of-the-art solutions during HTTP transfers, achieving up to 80% higher throughput while consuming 48% less energy. This work was presented at the IEEE CLOUD 2019 Conference.

(5) A novel two-phase dynamic throughput and energy optimization model that utilizes an offline decision-search-tree based clustering technique to encapsulate and categorize historical data transfer log information and an online search optimization algorithm to find the best application and kernel layer parameter combination to maximize the achieved data transfer throughput while minimizing the energy consumption. The experimental evaluation results show that this decision-tree based model outperforms the state-of-the-art solutions in this area by achieving 117% higher throughput on average and also consuming 19% less energy at the end systems during active data transfers. This work was presented at IEEE ICCCN 2022 Conference.

(6) A novel framework called Unified Regression Modelling (URegM), which predicts the impact of code smell refactoring on cloud resource usage. Resource utilization optimization is a significant challenge for cloud service providers, and this model will permit cloud service providers with advanced knowledge about the impact of refactoring code smells on resource consumption, thus allowing them to plan their resource provisioning and code refactoring more. This work was presented at ACM ESSE 2022 Conference.

(7) A novel deep reinforcement learning-based adaptive bitrate algorithm, called GreenABR, that optimizes the energy consumption during video streaming without sacrificing the user quality of experience. Deep reinforcement learning model makes no assumptions about the streaming environment and learns how to adapt to the dynamically changing conditions in a wide range of real network scenarios. This algorithm outperforms the existing state-of-the-art adaptive bitrate algorithms by saving up to 57% in streaming energy consumption and 60% in data consumption while achieving up to 22% more perceptual quality of experience due to up to 84% less rebuffering time and near-zero capacity violations. This work was presented at ACM MMSys 2022 Conference.

Broader Impacts:

This project resulted in the training and professional development of nine graduate students (six Ph.D. and three M.S.) and six undergraduate students through active participation in the research tasks of the project. Two of these Ph.D. students are now pursuing academic careers as Assistant Professors, and one is working at a prestigious industry research lab. Five undergraduate students and three M.S. students have joined the IT workforce. Some of the project's research outcomes have been incorporated into the graduate-level curriculum at the University at Buffalo. Overall, the solutions provided by GreenDataFlow will fill an essential gap in data transfer energy efficiency. The models, algorithms, and tools developed as part of this project will help to increase the performance and decrease the power consumption during end-to-end data transfers for a wide range of applications from different disciplines, saving significant gigawatt hours of energy and millions of dollars to the U.S. economy.
